meanings.def: having a surface that is not even or regular
examples: rough ground
The skin on her hands was hard and rough.
Trim rough edges with a sharp knife.
The car is designed for travelling over rough ground.
It has a slightly rough texture.

meanings.def: not exact; not including all details
examples: a rough calculation/estimate of the cost
I've got a rough idea of where I want to go.
There were about 20 people there, at a rough guess.
a rough draft of a speech
a rough sketch
It's only a very rough guide.
We only had his rather rough version of events.
He gave us a rough estimate of how much the work would cost.
I made a rough sketch of the inside of the church.

meanings.def: not gentle or careful; violent
examples: This watch is not designed for rough treatment.
They complained of rough handling by the guards.
She doesn't like playing with the rough kids.
Don't try any rough stuff with me!
Things got a bit rough, and the police were called.
You don't have to be so rough!
One carer was sacked for being rough with a patient.

meanings.def: where there is a lot of violence or crime
examples: the roughest neighbourhood in the city
He had been brought up in a rough area of London.

meanings.def: having large and dangerous waves; wild and with storms
examples: It was too rough to sail that night.
We had a rough passage across to the island.
They set sail in rough conditions.
There's no way he could have swum ashore in such rough weather.
There were rough seas in the area at that time.

meanings.def: difficult and unpleasant
examples: He's had a really rough time recently (= he's had a lot of problems).
We'll get someone in to do the rough work (= the hard physical work).
You two are obviously going through a rough patch right now.
You had to stand in the train all night?—That's a bit rough.
Life was rough on the streets.

meanings.def: not feeling well
examples: You look rough—are you OK?
I had a rough night (= I didn't sleep well).
I'm still feeling a bit rough.

meanings.def: simply made and not finished in every detail; plain or basic
examples: rough wooden tables
a rough track
(British English) rough paper for making notes on

meanings.def: not smooth or pleasant to taste, listen to, etc.
examples: a rough wine/voice
Her voice was rough with emotion.
‘I suppose you expect me to apologize for this,’ he said in a rough voice.

meanings.def: to experience/not experience difficulties when you are doing something; to make things difficult/easy for somebody
examples: He will be given a rough ride at the party conference.
The new teacher was given a rough ride by the class.

meanings.def: to experience difficulties when you are doing something; to make things difficult for somebody
examples: He will be given a rough ride at the party conference.

meanings.def: the fact of being treated unfairly
(to have some) small parts, for example in a performance or in your character, that are not yet as good as they should be
examples: The ballet still had some rough edges.
He had a few rough edges knocked off at school.
The films are very rough around the edges.

meanings.def: a situation in which somebody is treated badly or unfairly

idioms.def: the fact of being treated unfairly

idioms.idiom: (have some) rough edges | be rough around the edges

idioms.idiom: the rough end of the pineapple
idioms.def: a situation in which somebody is treated badly or unfairly

meanings.def: the part of a golf course where the grass is long, making it more difficult to hit the ball
examples: His second shot ended up in the rough.

meanings.def: the first version of a drawing or design that has been done quickly and without much detail
examples: Only the best of the roughs are shown to the editor.

meanings.def: a violent person
examples: a gang of roughs

meanings.def: a person of a low social class who has a sexual relationship with somebody of a higher class
if you write or draw something in rough, you make a first version of it, not worrying too much about mistakes or details
examples: Write it out in rough first then copy it neatly into your notebook.

meanings.def: to accept the unpleasant or difficult things that happen in life as well as the good things

idioms.def: a person of a low social class who has a sexual relationship with somebody of a higher class

idioms.idiom: take the rough with the smooth
idioms.def: to accept the unpleasant or difficult things that happen in life as well as the good things

meanings.def: to live in a way that is not very comfortable for a short time
examples: We can sleep on the beach. I don't mind roughing it for a night or two.

idioms.def: to live in a way that is not very comfortable for a short time
examples: We can sleep on the beach. I don't mind roughing it for a night or two.

meanings.def: using force or violence
examples: Do they always play this rough?

meanings.def: to live or sleep outdoors, usually because you have no home and no money
examples: young people sleeping rough on the streets

idioms.def: to live or sleep outdoors, usually because you have no home and no money
examples: young people sleeping rough on the streets
